revised 19 March 1996; accepted 20 March 1996 Abstract Alumina-, titania- and zirconia-supported iron oxides with an Fe loading of 5 wt.-% have been prepared by direct reduction of the precursors from incipient wetness impregnation and used for the synthesis of CZ+-hydrocarbons from COZ and HZ. According to the conversion of CO2, the catalytic activity decreases in the following order: Fe/Ti02(B) - Fe/Zr02(B) > Fe/Ti02(A) > Fe/Zr02(A) > Fe/A1203. XRD, Raman, Msbauer and EXAFS analyses are employed for the characterization of the catalysts following the reduction treatment. The results suggest that conversion of COZ to hydrocarbons is favored by the simultaneous presence of both zerovalent irons and coordinatively unsaturated cationic irons, among which ferric ions are for the Fe/Zr02(B) and ferrous ions for the Fe/Ti02(B). Keywords: Iron; COZ hydrogenation; Raman; Msbauer; EXAFS 1. Introduction Although a large number of investigations have been made on CO hydrogenation, so far relatively little attention has been paid to the conversion of CO2 into hydrocarbons [1]. It has been described [2-11] that the hydrogenation of COZ is generally much more selective toward methane over supported Group VIII metals. Some investigations have dealt with the production of C2+-hydrocarbons Corresponding author. 0926-860X/96/$17.00 Copyright 1997 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved. Suo et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 148 (1997) 307-313 (C2+ are hydrocarbons other than methane) from COZ and HZ [12-23], but much of them shown very poor selectivity. In this respect, iron-based catalysts seem to have potential [ 16-23]. In this paper, A1203-, Ti02- and Zr02_SUP_ ported iron catalysts were prepared and used for the synthesis of C2+-hydrocarbons from CO2 and H2. Catalytic performances and surface structures of supported iron oxide catalysts have been extensively studied by many authors [24-33]. It has been demonstrated that the iron cations are almost saturated by adventitious oxygen after calcination. Removing these oxygens will be difficult due to the geometric stability of the octahedral coordinated iron sites [34,35]. Such a catalyst cannot give high activity in CO hydrogenation because it does not adsorb CO [31,32]. In order to decrease the coordination number of the iron cations and further form the coordinatively unsaturated surface iron species at the interface of iron oxides and the support, a novel preparation strategy has been proposed in our previous studies [34,35], i.e., the catalyst precursors obtained by incipient wetness impregnation are directly reduced in H 2 atmosphere at proper temperature without calcination. 2. Experimental 2.1. Catalyst preparation The supports employed in this study were y-A1203, Ti02 and Zr02. The -y-A'203 support was obtained commercially without any pretreatment. Both Ti02 and ZrO., supports were obtained in two ways. The commercially available Ti02(A) was calcined at 473 K for 2 h. The Ti02(B) was prepared by the hydrolysis of Ti(i-01304. After filtering, the white precipitate obtained was dried at 393 K and calcined at 873 K for 5 h. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis revealed that the Ti02(A) is only in anatase form and the Ti02(B) consisted of ca. 15% rutile and ca. 85% anatase. The Zr02(A) was prepared by the hydrolysis of an aqueous ZrOC12 solution with dilute ammonia. After filtering and washing repeatedly with de-ionized water to remove chloride ions, the white precipitate obtained was dried at 393 K and calcined at 873 K for 5 h. The Zr02(B) was obtained from the decomposition of Zr(OH)4 at 873 K for 5 h. XRD confirmed that both Zr02(A) and Zr02(B) were mainly in monoclinic form. All supports were crushed to particles of 30-60 mesh. The surface areas of the supports determined by BET method were as follows: -y-A1203 150; Ti02(A) 7; Ti02(B) 20; Zr02(A) 24; and Zr02(B) 27 m2/g. Supported iron oxide samples with an Fe loading of 5 wt.-% were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation of the supports with an aqueous solution of hydrated ferric nitrate. The precursors obtained were dried carefully at 393 K overnight. The carefully dried precursors were reduced in situ in flow H 2 atmosphere at 773 K for 5 h and direct calcination was avoided. Z.-h. Suo et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 148 (1997) 301-313 303 2.2. Hydrogenation of COZ The hydrogenation of COZ was carried out using a stainless steel fixed-bed flow microreactor. The carefully dried sample (about 1 ml) was mounted in the stainless steel reactor tube (I.D. = 8 mm) and then reduced in HZ at 773 K for 5 h. After cooling to the reaction temperature (623 K), the HZ flow was replaced with a pre-mixed feed gas (HZ:COZ = 2:1). The feed gas was purified by passage through 3A and 13X molecular sieve traps at room temperature to remove probable impurities, such as water or alcohol. The pressure of the feed gas was 1.5 MPa and the space velocity of the stream of educts was generally 800-1000 ml ml-'cat h-'. After the reaction went on for 2-4 h, the conversion of COZ and the distribution of the products did not change evidently. At the time, the products were analyzed by using on-line gas chromatography. Analysis of C 1-C 5 hydrocarbons was carried out in a quartz capillary column coated with alumina using a flame ionization detector, but higher hydrocarbons were not detected with the column. Analyses of CO and COZ were performed in a carbon molecular sieve column using a thermal conductivity detector. Blank test runs showed that the catalytic effects of the reactor wall and the supports were negligible under the reaction temperature. 2.3. XRD and Raman measurements A D/MAX-RB X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan) operating with Cu Ka radiation was used to determine the crystalline phases present. X-ray diffraction studies were performed on all the samples prepared. The Raman spectra of titania and titanic-supported iron samples were collected in a Raman apparatus (Model 1403, Spex). The 514.5 nm line of an argon ion laser was used as the excitation source. Titania was also reduced at 773 K for 5 h. Under the protection of NZ atmosphere, the reduced samples were sealed in a specimen tube and used directly in the measurement without exposure to air. 2.4. Msbauer measurement All 5' Fe-Msbauer spectra were taken at room temperature in an MR-351 Msbauer spectrometer. The y-ray source consisted of 10 mCi of 57CO in a rhodium matrix. The oscillation was in constant acceleration mode. The reduced sample was made by directly applying the powders on Scotch tape and sealing under NZ atmosphere and then measured at room temperature immediately. The velocity scale in all spectra was reported relative to metallic iron, which was also the reference standard for isomer shift calculation. All spectra were analyzed and fitted with a set of independent Lorentzians, with the help of a nonlinear least-squares fitting procedure. Usually it was assumed that the 304 Z-h. Suo et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 148 (1997) 301-313 Mdssbauer area ratios are equal to a relative amount of the associated species. This approximation was commonly used in the pertinent literature [24,33]. 2.5. EXAFS measurement X-ray absorption spectra were obtained using the BL-7C facility at the Photon Factory (Tsukuba, Japan) with a positron beam energy of 2.5 GeV and an average stored current of 250 mA. Data were collected with a Si(311) doublecrystal monochromator in fluorescence mode. Spectra were recorded in four energy regions about the Fe K-edge: -100 to - 30 eV in 15 eV steps, - 30 to 70 eV in 0.5-eV steps, 70 to 700 eV in 4-eV steps, and above 700 eV in 8-eV steps. The energy calibration was set at 7111.0 eV at the Fe foil 3d pre-edge feature. The preparation procedure of the specimen was the same as the Mdssbauer measurement. The data were processed on an AST 486 microcomputer with the program library for EXAFS data processing written by the Institute of Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. A general procedure for the EXAFS (extended XAFS) analysis had been given previously [27,28,36]. 3. Results 3.1. A room temperature Msbauer spectrum of the reduced Fe/A1203 is shown in Fig. 2 and the corresponding Msbauer parameters are listed in Table 2. The spectrum is fitted with two doublets. The doublet with an isomer shift (IS) of 0.34 mm/s and a quadrupole splitting (QS) of 0.95 mm/s are indicative of ferric canons [24,43-45]. Thus, there is a strong possibility that some of the FeA1204 spinel has formed on the Fe/A1203. The sextuplet assigned to u.-Fe phase is not observed, indicating that the ferric cations on the Fe/A1203 cannot be easily reduced to zerovalent. Fig. 3 is the spectrum of the reduced Fe/Ti02(B). The spectrum is fitted with a singlet, a sextuplet and two doublets. The singlet has the only parameter of IS = 0.02 mm/s. It is due to the particles that are superparamagnetic zerovalent irons, represented as Fe[46]. The sextuplet has a hyperfine magnetic field of ca. 332.5 kOe, being assigned to a-Fe (330.0 kOe) [44-46]. The doublet A with IS = 1.36 mm/s and QS = 1.57 mm/s is assigned to the surface ferrous cations, representing as Fee+(A). The Fee+(A) species is probably coordinatively unsaturated due to large quadrupole splitting and isomer shift [24]. The doublet B with IS = 1.10 mm/s and QS = 0.73 mm/s has typical parameters of the ferrous cations in the FeTi03 phase, represented as Fez+(B) [24]. The ferric cation is not observed. Fig. 4 is the spectrum of the reduced Fe/Zr02(B). Compared with that of the Fe/Ti020, the spectrum is simple and consists of a sextuplet assigned to a-Fe and a doublet assigned to the ferric cations. It is noteworthy that the ferrous cation is not observed on the Fe/Zr02, implying that the ferrous cations are likely little stable on the zirconia surface. 3.4. Discussion The present results confirm that the catalytic activity of iron oxides in COZ hydrogenation depends upon the nature of the support used, such as the acidity, the preparation procedure and even the crystalline form of the support. In comparison with the Fe/Ti02(A), the low activity of the Fe/Ti02(A) suggests that the presence of the ruble phase in the Ti02 is beneficial to obtain high activity. This corresponds with the results obtained by Thampi about the hydrogenation of COZ [47] and by Kikuchi about the hydrogenation of CO [48] over the Ti02-supported Ru catalyst. Although both Zr02(A) and Zr02(B) are in monoclinic form, the activity of the Fe/Zr02(A) is lower than that of the Fe/Zr02(B). It is believed that this is due to the residual chloride ions on the Zr02(A) [49,50]. X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) has confirmed that a small amount of chloride ions are present Z-h. Suo et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 148 (1997) 301-313 311 on the Zr0z(A). The presence of residual chloride ions decreases apparently the adsorption property of the catalyst and further makes the catalytic activity low [50]. It has been confirmed that the Fe/Ti02(B) catalyst after calcination displays very low catalytic activity in CO hydrogenation because CO is not adsorbed on the surface of the Fe/Zr02 [29,31,32]. It is believed that this is due to the formation of coordinately saturated hematite. It is difficult for the hematite to be reduced to coordinatively unsaturated ferrous species or zerovalent irons based on the geometric stability of octahedral coordinated cation sites. As described by the previous EXAFS analysis [27,35,36], the iron cations on the A1203 surface are in potentially six-fold octahedral sites and easily saturated by adventitious oxygen. Hence, it is very difficult to be reduced to zerovalence even under very severe conditions [44]. However, in the Fe/Ti02(B) and Fe/Zr02(B), reduction firstly removes the adsorbed oxygen on the surface and then creates some oxygen vacancies to form surface species with coordinatively unsaturated sites. As a result, the catalytic activity enhances because more active sites will be exposed to the surface. However, as observed by the results reported elsewhere [35,51], high-temperature reduction (e.g., Fe/Ti02(B) reduced at 823 K) will damage the appropriate surface structure and cause some structural change such as restructuring of the surface because of the decrease in the number of oxygen atoms. This will result in abrupt decreasing catalytic activity. It is well known that the hydrogenation of COz proceeds via the CO intermediate [7-9,12,22,23,37]. That is, during the hydrogenation of COZ over the supported Fe catalysts, some of the COZ is firstly converted through a reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction to CO and CO formed is converted consecutively through a Fischer-Tropsch reaction to hydrocarbons. It has been suggested that iron oxides are active for the RWGS reaction [26,52,53] and zerovalent irons are beneficial to the formation of lower olefins [36]. Therefore, it is proposed that the combination of zerovalent and cationic irons will likely give higher activity and more hydrocarbons for the hydrogenation of COZ [34,35]. Obviously, the cationic irons should be coordinatively unsaturated. The active iron species are probably a-Fe and Fee+(A) ions for the Fe/Ti020. The Fee+(B) cations in the FeTi03 are generally inactive because they are located in coordinatively saturated sites [24,42]. In comparison with conventionally prepared Fe203/Ti02 [30], the significantly reduced coordination number of the first Fe-O shell are observed in the Fe/Ti02(B). The lower coordination number is thought to be mainly due to the formation of zerovalent irons as well as the formation of coordinatively unsaturated Fee+(A). The latter is important for the high activity achieved by the Fe/Ti0z(B) [35]. Further experimental evidence comes from the Fe/Ti02(B) reduced at 823 K which gives very low activity [35,51]. There were about 30.3% zerovalent irons but not any Fee+(A) as observed by the Msbauer spectrum. For the Fe/Zr02(B), the ferrous cations are not present, but the ferric cations are observed. The ferric 312 Z.-h. Suo et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 148 (1997) 301-313 cations are also coordinatively unsaturated as confirmed by EXAFS analysis [54]. So in the Fe/Zr02(B), the cations which play an important role in the RWGS reaction are probably the ferric cations. Since the combination of both zerovalent and cationic irons may significantly inhibit the secondary hydrogenation, Ti02(B)- and Zr02(B)-supported iron oxide catalysts show good selectivity to C2+-hydrocarbon. It can be expected that the catalyst with the optimum ratio of iron cations versus zerovalent irons should give good catalytic activity and selectivity in the synthesis of Cz+-hydrocarbons from COZ and H2. 5. Conclusions Supported iron oxide catalysts have been prepared successfully by direct reduction of the precursor obtained from incipient wetness impregnation. The catalytic activity is affected by the support used. Titania- and zirconia-supported iron oxides show good activity and selectivity in the synthesis of C2+-hydrocarbons from COZ and H2. The results given by Mdssbauer spectra and EXAFS analyses reveal that the conversion of COz and Hz to hydrocarbons is favored in the presence of both zerovalent irons and coordinatively unsaturated cationic irons, which are Fee+(A) cations for Fe/Ti02(B) and Fe 3+ ions for Fe/Zr02(B). Alumina-, titania- and zirconia-supported iron oxides with an Fe loading of 5 wt.-% have been prepared by direct reduction of the precursors from incipient wetness impregnation and used for the synthesis of C2+-hydrocarbons from CO2 and H2. According to the conversion of CO2, the catalytic activity decreases in the following order: Fe TiO2(B) ∼ Fe ZrO2(B) > Fe TiO2(A) > Fe ZrO2(A) > Fe Al2O3 . XRD, Raman, Mössbauer and EXAFS analyses are employed for the characterization of the catalysts following the reduction treatment. The results suggest that conversion of CO2 to hydrocarbons is favored by the simultaneous presence of both zerovalent irons and coordinatively unsaturated cationic irons, among which ferric ions are for the Fe/ZrO2(B) and ferrous ions for the Fe/TiO2(B).
